chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect chronic kidney disease?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Arrange investigations to assess for chronic kidney disease (CKD) in people with:

  • Risk factors for CKD.
  • An incidental finding of:
    • Raised serum creatinine and/or a serum estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of less than 60 mL/min/1.73 m2.
    • Proteinuria (a urinary albumin:creatinine ratio [ACR] of more than 3 mg/mmol).
    • Persistent haematuria (two out of three urine dipstick tests show 1+ or more of blood), after exclusion of a urinary tract infection (UTI). See the CKS topics on Urinary tract infection (lower) - men and Urinary tract infection (lower) - women for more information.
    • Urine sediment abnormalities, such as red blood cells (may indicate glomerular disease); white blood cells (may indicate pyelonephritis or interstitial nephritis); or granular casts and renal tubular epithelial cells (seen in many parenchymal diseases).
  • Possible clinical features of CKD. Be aware that disease is often asymptomatic in the early stages.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to suspect chronic kidney disease (CKD) are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Chronic kidney disease. Early identification and management of chronic kidney disease in adults in primary and secondary care [NICE, 2015a], the Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) CKD Work Group publication KDIGO 2012 Clinical practice guideline for the evaluation and management of chronic kidney disease [KDIGO, 2013], and expert opinion in review articles on CKD [Fraser, 2016; Vassalotti, 2016; Bello, 2017; Webster, 2017].

Investigating people with risk factors for CKD

  • The aim of early identification and treatment of CKD is to decrease the risk of cardiovascular disease, progression to end-stage renal disease (ESRD), and mortality. The recommendation to investigate people with risk factors for CKD is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2015a] and expert opinion in review articles [Fraser, 2016; Vassalotti, 2016; Webster, 2017]. This approach is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • This recommendation is based on high-quality individual patient data meta-analyses [NICE, 2015a].
    • NICE concluded that general population screening is not cost-effective, but targeted screening directed at high-risk groups is cost-effective, as it helps to identify people with CKD at an earlier disease stage who may benefit most from ongoing monitoring and management to reduce the risk of complications and disease progression.
    • The guideline development group reviewed the evidence on risk factors for CKD (assessing three cohort and 16 observational or cross-sectional studies) and confirmed that risk factors were strongly associated with an increased risk of a diagnosis of CKD or progression of pre-existing disease.
    • NICE did not find strong evidence to recommend routine testing for CKD in people who smoke, have a high alcohol intake, have abnormal lipids, are obese (in the absence of metabolic syndrome), are from a lower socioeconomic group, or who come from any particular ethnic group.

Investigating people with incidental test result findings

  • Expert opinion in a review article notes that CKD is often an incidental finding [Vassalotti, 2016].
  • The NICE clinical guideline states that the presence of proteinuria or haematuria indicates a high risk of CKD [NICE, 2015a].
  • The information on the possible significance of urine sediment abnormalities is based on the KDIGO guideline on CKD [KDIGO, 2013] and expert opinion in a review article [Webster, 2017].

Investigating people with possible symptoms of CKD

  • The recommendation to investigate people with possible symptoms of CKD is extrapolated from expert opinion in review articles [Bello, 2017; Webster, 2017] and is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
  • The information that CKD is often asymptomatic in the early stages is based on expert opinion in review articles [Fraser, 2016; Webster, 2017].
